sen.j: 勧修寺 晴子（かじゅうじ はるこ、天文 (元号)22年（1553年） － 元和 6年2月18日 （1620年3月21日））は、正親町天皇の第五皇子誠仁親王の妃。
sen.e: Haruko KAJUJI (born 1553, died February 18 (March 21), 1620) was the wife of Imperial Prince Sanehito, the fifth son of Emperor Ogimachi.
Haruko KAJUJI (born 1553, died February 18 (March 21), 1620) was the wife of Imperial Prince Sanehito, the fifth son of Emperor Ogimachi.
Haruko KAJUJI (born 1553, died March 21, 1620) was the wife of Imperial Prince Sanehito, the fifth son of Emperor Ogimachi.
sen.cmt: 新暦のみの記載にしました。

sen.j: 父は勧修寺晴右で、母は従三位粟屋元子。
sen.e: Her father was Haruhide KAJUJI, and her mother was Jusani (Junior Third Rank) Motoko AWAYA.
Her father was Haruhide KAJUJI, and her mother was Jusani (Junior Third Rank) Motoko AWAYA.
Her father was Haruhide KAJUJI, and her mother was Jusani (Junior Third Rank) Motoko AWAYA.

sen.j: 勧修寺晴豊、万里小路充房、正親町三条公仲室らの姉妹。
sen.e: Her siblings included Haretoyo [Harutoyo] KAJUJI, Atsufusa MADENOKOJI and Kiminaka OGIMACHI-SANJO.
Her siblings included Haretoyo [Harutoyo] KAJUJI, Atsufusa MADENOKOJI and Kiminaka OGIMACHI-SANJO.
Her siblings included Haretoyo (Harutoyo) KAJUJI, Atsufusa MADENOKOJI and Kiminaka OGIMACHISANJO.

sen.j: 子に後陽成天皇、空性法親王、良恕法親王、八条宮智仁親王、永邵女王など6男3女がいる。
sen.e: She had 6 sons and 3 daughters such as Emperor Goyozei, Imperial Prince Kusho, Imperial Prince Ryojo, Imperial Prince Hachijo-no-miya Toshihito and Princess Eisho.
She had 6 sons and 3 daughters such as Emperor Goyozei, Imperial Prince Kusho, Imperial Prince Ryojo, Imperial Prince Hachijo-no-miya Toshihito and Princess Eisho.
She had 6 sons and 3 daughters such as Emperor Goyozei, Imperial Prince Kusho, Imperial Prince Ryojo, Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Toshihito and Princess Eisho.

sen.j: 母の実家、粟屋氏は甲斐源氏安田氏の一族で、安田義定の子孫である。
sen.e: Her mother was from the Awaya clan belonging to the Kai-Genji Yasuda clan; therefore, she was a descendant of Yoshisada YASUDA.
Her mother was from the Awaya clan belonging to the Kai-Genji Yasuda clan; therefore, she was a descendant of Yoshisada YASUDA.
Her mother was from the Awaya clan belonging to the Kai-Genji Yasuda clan; therefore, she was a descendant of Yoshisada YASUDA.

sen.j: 当時は同族で若狭国守護であった武田氏の最有力家臣であり武家の名門の家柄。
sen.e: The family was the most powerful vassal of the Takeda clan, who belonged to the same family and served as Shugo (provincial constable) of Wakasa Province; therefore, her lineage was a prestigious samurai family.

The family was the most powerful vassal of the Takeda clan, who belonged to the same family and served as Shugo (provincial constable) of Wakasa Province; therefore, her lineage was a prestigious samurai family.

The family was the most powerful vassal of the Takeda clan, who belonged to the same family and served as Shugo (provincial constable) of Wakasa Province; therefore, her lineage was a prestigious samurai family.

sen.j: 1567年（永禄10年）誠仁親王に嫁し、阿茶局と称した。
sen.e: In 1567, she married Imperial Prince Sanehito, and named herself Acha-no-tsubone.
In 1567, she married Imperial Prince Sanehito, and named herself Acha-no-tsubone.
In 1567, she married Imperial Prince Sanehito, and named herself Acha no tsubone.

sen.j: 彼女の産んだ後陽成天皇即位後の1586年（天正14年）11月に准三宮となった。
sen.e: In November 1586, she became Jusangu (honorary rank next to the three Empresses: Great Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress) after the enthronement of her son, Emperor Goyozei.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In November 1586, she became Jusangu (honorary rank next to the three Empresses: Great Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress) after the enthronement of her son, Emperor Goyozei.
In December 1586, she became Jusangu (honorary rank next to the three Empresses: Great Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress) after the enthronement of her son, Emperor Goyozei.

sen.j: 1600年（慶長5年）12月29日院号宣下により女院となり新上東門院と号した。
sen.e: On December 29, 1600, she was permitted to use ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) and became nyoin to name herself Shinjotomonin.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On December 29, 1600, she was permitted to use ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) and became nyoin to name herself Shinjotomonin.

On February 2, 1601, she was permitted to use ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) and became nyoin to name herself Shinjotomonin.

sen.j: 元和6年2月18日、68歳で崩御した。
sen.e: She demised on February 18, 1601, at age 68.
She died on February 18, 1601, at age 68.
She died on March 21, 1620, at age 68.
sen.cmt: 旧暦を新暦に訂正しました。

sen.j: 墓は京都泉湧寺月輪陵域にある。
sen.e: She was buried in Tsukinowa-no-Misasagi at Sennyu-ji Temple in Kyoto.
She was buried in Tsukinowa-no-Misasagi at Sennyu-ji Temple in Kyoto.
She was buried in Tsukinowa no misasagi at Sennyu-ji Temple in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: Tsukinowa no misasagiに訂正しました。
